citations.narrative:
The facility is conducting regulated activity without a valid USDA license. The facility consigned a 4-month-old male
African Crested Porcupine to a licensed dealer on 5/21/25, without having a USDA license of their own to sell the animal.
A family member’s recently expired (3/29/2025) USDA transporter registration number was documented to be given to the
licensed dealer for consignment of the animal. They later stated to the inspector that they believed that the registration
allowed for conducting regulated activity as described by the Animal Welfare Act.
In addition, the facility advertises hands-on exotic animal experiences on their Facebook page, which promotes the
exhibition of covered species such as red kangaroos, six-banded armadillos, and African crested porcupine. The facility
submitted an initial application for USDA licensure on 09/15/22, but they did not complete the license requirements for
conducting regulated activity as outlined under the Animal Welfare Act.
A valid USDA license is required to operate as a dealer or exhibitor as set forth in the Animal Welfare Act. This is
necessary to ensure the health and well-being of the animals and to comply with the Regulations.
Correct by obtaining a USDA license or discontinuing regulated activity. No regulated activities may be conducted until a
USDA license is obtained.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.1(a)(1) 
   
Requirements and application. 
The facility is conducting regulated activity without a valid USDA license. The facility consigned a 4-month-old male 
African Crested Porcupine to a licensed dealer on 5/21/25, without having a USDA license of their own to sell the animal. 
A family member’s recently expired (3/29/2025) USDA transporter registration number was documented to be given to the 
licensed dealer for consignment of the animal. They later stated to the inspector that they believed that the registration 
allowed for conducting regulated activity as described by the Animal Welfare Act.  
 
In addition, the facility advertises hands-on exotic animal experiences on their Facebook page, which promotes the 
exhibition of covered species such as red kangaroos, six-banded armadillos, and African crested porcupine. The facility 
submitted an initial application for USDA licensure on 09/15/22, but they did not complete the license requirements for 
conducting regulated activity as outlined under the Animal Welfare Act. 
 
A valid USDA license is required to operate as a dealer or exhibitor as set forth in the Animal Welfare Act. This is 
necessary to ensure the health and well-being of the animals and to comply with the Regulations. 
 
Correct by obtaining a USDA license or discontinuing regulated activity. No regulated activities may be conducted until a 
USDA license is obtained. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
